explanation:
Rationale for each required symbol (short):

- OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl: Direct callee; its implementation must be inspected for any for-loops (MISRA for-loop rule applies to called functions because the behaviour of the loop body includes called functions). Also it may read/modify objects that a loop in this or called code could reference.

- OS_TaskGetId_Impl: Direct callee of OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl call chain; must be checked for loops/side-effects that could interact with loop counters or loop control flags.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee; its implementation may call further helpers and contain for-loops or persistent side-effects. The correctness of any for-loop in called code influences whether the target function violates the MISRA rule.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Appears as a helper used by the object-id APIs; include because it (or its transitive callees) may contain for-loops or modify objects that a loop control expression must not use.

- OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl: Direct callee that is passed the token and timebase_prop; its body must be inspected for for-loops (especially any that might use or modify objects from the caller or violate the single-counter constraint).

- OS_ObjectIdRelease: Direct callee; its implementation (and transitive callees) must be checked for for-loops and side-effects that count toward the behaviour of the target function.

- OS_printf: Direct callee (present in static call graph); logging functions sometimes contain loops; must be checked because called functions are part of loop behaviour analysis.

- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: These test-stub/handler symbols appear in the static call graph for the target (test harness instrumentation). If any of these are linked/invoked, their implementations could contain for-loops or side-effects relevant to the MISRA analysis; include to be conservative.

- OS_CHECK_POINTER: Macro used at start of the function. Its expansion may contain control-flow or calls (and thus loops) or side-effects that affect compliance; must be seen to ensure no forbidden loop usage or modifications to objects used in potential for-loop clauses.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro used to obtain record/timebase pointers from global tables. Macro expansion might perform indexing or other operations; inspect to ensure it does not introduce for-loops or modify objects used by loops.

- OS_global_timebase_table, OS_timebase_table: Objects referenced via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. Their types and accessors may be implemented with loops; must be inspected in context of called functions that access them.

- OS_common_record_t, OS_timebase_internal_record_t, OS_timebase_prop_t: Types of objects read/written by the function. If any called function contains for-loops that reference or modify fields of these objects they must be examined to ensure loop counters and control flags obey the MISRA constraints (e.g., loops must not use objects that are modified in loop bodies elsewhere).

- OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE: Constants/return codes used in control flow. Needed to understand which branches execute (and therefore which callees/run-time behaviours are relevant) so we can determine which functions/loops are in the effective behavior.

- memset, strncpy: Standard library functions invoked. Although usually simple, their implementations (or wrappers used in this project) must be known/assumed safe for MISRA for-loop checks because called functions contribute to loop behaviour. At minimum, include to confirm they do not contain problematic for-loops or side-effects on loop-control objects.

Notes: The MISRA requirement to treat the behaviour of the loop body as including any called functions means the analysis must inspect the bodies of all direct callees and relevant transitive helpers (especially OS_ObjectIdGetById and OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl and any object-id helper functions). The above list is conservative: it covers the direct callees seen in the static call graph plus macros, global tables and types referenced by the target function so the next analyzer can open those definitions and verify there are no for-loops that violate the rule or use/modify objects in a way that would make a for-loop ill-formed according to MISRA.
